analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received September 15, 2017; revised October 29, 2017; accepted November 21, 2017.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: For decreasing communication load and overcoming network constrains, such as the limited bandwidth and data loss in multi-agent networks, this paper integrates the two control strategies to investigate the bounded consensus problem of multiagent systems (MASs) with external disturbance on the basis of an undirected graph, namely, the quantized control and the eventtriggered control. In the existence of the external disturbance, two types of the high-gain control laws with the uniform quantized relative state measurements for the bounded consensus problem of MASs are first discussed, respectively. Then, in order to save the limited network resources in a multi-agent network, the eventtriggered quantized communication protocols are designed based on the first case to obtain the bounded consensus in multi-agent systems. Moreover, it is shown that "Zeno behavior" phenomenon can be excluded under the two event-triggered quantized control mechanisms, and the boundness of the relative state error can be adjusted by selecting the different parameters. Finally, two examples are shown to validate the feasibility and efficiency of our theoretical analysis.

some complex tasks that are incapable of individual. Consensus or synchronization problem is hot issue in multi-agent systems, and its ami to develop a control protocol such that all states of all agents converge to a common value by interacting with its own neighbors. Some well works on consensus or synchronization have been reported in [1]- [10] and reference therein.

On the other hand, the network plays a key role in communication among agents and can improve the control efficiency. However, some constraints are unavoidable in communication network. Quantized control approach [11]- [13], as an effective control strategy, can deal with those limitations in network systems and quantized consensus problem in [14] and [15] can be obtained by adopting quantized control, where uniform quantizer in [16]- [23] has been popular with researchers. For example, [16], [17] adopted uniform quantizer to address the consensus of single-integrator discrete-time MASs. However, it failed to find a traditional root for rightside of discontinuous right-hand sides of differential equations when investigating continuous-time MASs with quantized communication. In [18], Fransca discussed the convergence of Krasovskii solution [19] for the continuous-time quantized consensus with time-varying directed topology. [20] introduced the incidence matrix instead of the Laplacian matrix to the consensus problem of state agreement with quantized measurements and the formation control. For general linear systems, [24], [25] adopted the Lyapunov method [26] to deal with the quantized consensus of MASs with eventtriggered strategy, where quantized relative state measurements are considered in [24] and [25]. Some inequality methods were used to solve the quantized consensus problem, where every agent's states were quantized in [26]- [28]. However, these works did not take into account any external disturbances.

It is well known that there exists the limited network resource for communication and controller update in agent networks since every agent works in a digital platform. In order to overall the problem, the advantages of the eventtriggered control are shown to solve the problem in multiagent systems [29], [30]. From then on, some works on ETC approach has been reported in [31]- [36]. [31] considered the consensus problem of MASs with fixed and switching topologies, and given the sufficient conditions for consensus. [33] adopted a mode-based approach to investigate the synchronization problem of leader-following MASs with time-dependent threshold and fixed threshold. In presence of multiple leaders, [34] investigated the containment control problem in MASs based on time-dependent threshold, where two cases were considered, one is that the leaders were opinionated, and the other is that the leaders were opinionated.

In the wide applications of multi-agent system in different fields, it is necessary for researchers to consider how to deal with communication constraints and how to save network resources. By combining the quantized control and the event-triggered control, the above problem can be solved with the following reasons. Firstly, there exist limited networked storage and interaction bandwidth in network control systems or MASs, and the quantized control approach can improve the limitation. Secondly, network resources are limited in communication network, and in order to obtain the better cooperative performance by reducing the inter-agent communication load, the event-triggered control shows its advantage to save network resources. Some existing results on quantized relative state measurements with a single integrator were given in [20]- [22] without taking into account the ETC strategy. [25] adopted two types of the quantizers (uniform and logarithmic quantizer) to study the consensus problem of MASs via event-triggered mechanism, where the dynamic of every agent is a single integrator and the relative state measurements are quantized. However, there were a few literatures which deal with the consensus of the general linear MASs by integrating quantized control and ETC in [23], [28], and [37], especially quantized relative state measurements [24]. Note that the Lyapunov function approach [20]- [22], [24], [28], [37] and the inequality approach [23], [26] are adopted to investigate the quantized consensus problem. The consensus of MASs with quantized agent's state was investigated in [26], [28], and [37]. [24] considered an event-triggered consensus of the general linear MASs with quantized relative state measurements in finite time and gave the sufficient condition of achieving consensus. Note that in [24], the triggering condition is more complicated and without external disturbances.

In this paper, the bounded consensus of general linear MASs with quantized relative state measurements and external disturbances via ETC mechanism is studied. The integration of the quantized control and the ETC has the advantages listed as follows.

1) Some existing results on the consensus of linear MASs with quantized relative state measurements have been reported in [20]- [22] and [25]. However, these works just considered the single-integrator dynamics for the agent. In this paper, we consider general linear MASs with quantized relative state measurements. Moreover, the external disturbance is also considered. 2) Two types of the consensus protocols are designed to investigate the bounded consensus of general linear multi-agent systems with quantized relative state measurements and non-bounded disturbance. Taking into account the external disturbance, a high gain method is proposed to recompense for the effects of the external disturbances.

3) The limited network resource is also a crucial factor for communication of agents, which leads to the ETC strategy being taken into account. The two kinds of quantized consensus protocol based on the event-triggered control (ETC) are introduced and two event-triggered functions based on the time-dependent threshold are designed to obtain bounded consensus of general linear MASs with external disturbance. A high gain approach is also suitable for this case. Moreover, it is shown that "Zeno behavior" is also excluded with our proposed consensus protocols. Meanwhile, the bounded consensus error can be adjusted by selecting the different parameters. 4) Compared with [26], [28], every agent requires to obtain relative information of neighbouring agents instead of achieving the global information and updates its control input in its own event-triggered time in this paper.

Another difference is that we investigate the edge Laplacian associated with the incidence matrix instead of the regular Laplacian matrix owing to the relative state measurements. The paper is organized as follows. Some definitions including graph theory, uniform quantizer, non-smooth analysis (differential inclusion and Krasovskii solution), problem formulation, and the objective of control are given in Section II. Section III and IV discusses the quantized consensus of MASs with external disturbance without and with the ETC approach, respectively. Two examples are offered to validate the feasibility and efficiency of our method in Section V. Finally, some conclusions are drawn in Section VI.

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.p: Communication way between agents can be described by the topology graph that can be founded in [38]. The topology graph G = (V, E, A) consists of a node set V = {v 1 , v 2 , . . . v N }, an edge set E ⊆ V × V, and an adjacency matrix A = [a i j ] ∈ N×N . G is called an undirected graph if and only if anda
div.formula: (v i , v j ) ∈ E (v j , v i ) ∈ E. For A = [a i j ], a i j = a j i = 1 if (i, j ) ∈ E,
i j = 0 otherwise. A path on G from node v i 1 to node v i m is a sequence of ordered edges in E of the form (v i m , v i m+1 ), m = 1, 2, . . . , l -1.
div.p: An undirected graph is connected if between any two different nodes, there is a path between them. The in-degree matrix D in G is defined as D = di ag(deg in (1)
div.formula: , . . . deg in (N)), where deg in (i ) = N j =1,i = j a i j . The Laplacian matrix L = [l i j ] in G is defined as L = D -A, where l i j = N j =1
div.p: , j =i a i j and l i j = -a i j , i = j .

Assume that G = ( Ṽ, Ẽ) is any one subgraph of graph G, where the node set Ṽ ⊂ V and the edge set E ⊂ E. The incidence matrix M ∈ N×M in G is described by as m i j = 1 if node i is the tail of edge (i, j ); m i j = -1 if node i is the head of edge (i, j ); otherwise, m i j = 0. Then, we can have that in an undirected graph G, 1 T N M = 0 and L = M T M. By introducing the incidence matrix M, we can design the relative state vector η η η in [25] as

div.head: B. Quantisation
div.p: A uniform quantizer q u : → . is defined as follows.
div.formula: q u (x) = θ x θ + 1 2 , (2
div.p: where θ > 0 represents the gain of uniform quantizer. Define u as quantisation error and u satisfies the following equation

where the quantisation error u ∈ (-θ 2 , θ 2 ) responses to the accuracy of the quantizer directly and satisfies |q u (x)-x| ≤ θ 2 for all x ∈ . According to the definition of a uniform quantizer, it is also suitable for vector case. For example, for any vector x = [x 1 , . . . , x N ] T , define the vector uniform quantisation q v (•) : n → n to be q v (x x x) ≡ [q v (x 1 ), . . . , q v (x n )] T . Then, we can obtain the following result: q v (x x x)x x x ≤ n θ 2 . Due to the uniform quantization effect, complete consensus cannot be ensured, but only bounded consensus can be achieved. That is, all the states of agents enter into a ball which is centered at the desired synchronization equilibrium and never flow out, the radius of this ball can be estimated.

div.head: C. Non-Smooth Analysis
div.p: For a differential equation [40],

where f (x(t), t): × n → n is a measurable and discontinuous function. Note that the existence of a continuously differential equation solution is not guaranteed. Hence, the Krasovskii solution is introduced to discuss the solution of the differential equation. A vector function x(t) is called the Krasovskii solution of Eq.( 4) on [t 0 , t 1 ) if x(t) is absolutely continuous on [t 0 , t 1 ), and satisfies
where co denotes the convex closure and B(x, δ) is the Euclidean ball centred in x with the radius δ. If f (•) is measurable and locally bounded, then x is the Krasovskill solution of Eq.( 4).

div.head: D. Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider a MAS consisting of N identical agents with general linear dynamics. The model of the i -th agent (i = 1, . . . N) can be expressed as follows, similar to [41]
div.formula: ẋi (t) = Ax i (t) + B[u i (t) + w i (t)], i = 1, . . . N,(6)
div.p: where x i ∈ n is the state vector of the i -th agent, u i ∈ m is the control input vector of i -th agent. A is the gain matrix with approximate dimensions and B denotes input matrix with approximate dimensions. w i ∈ q denotes the external disturbance. For systems (6), the N agents are required to satisfy the following assumptions. Assumption 1: The pair (A, B) is controllable.
Assumption 2 [41]: There exists positive integer χ such that
div.formula: w i ≤ χ i , i = 1, . . . N.
div.p: The control objective of this paper is to investigate the bounded consensus of general linear multi-agent systems with quantized relative state measurements and external disturbances. Due to the limited network bandwidth in a communication network, the quantized consensus of MASs is discussed based on the two controllers, respectively. Then, an eventtriggered control strategy on the basis of the previous two cases is designed to solve the consensus problem. Moreover, we need to prove that "Zeno behavior" can be excluded.

div.head: III. QUANTIZED CONSENSUS PROTOCOL
div.p: Consider the storage and the communication bandwidth among agents in multi-agent networks, quantized control approach, as an effective control strategy, can deal with these limitations. Thus, in this section, we discuss the quantized control for the bounded consensus problem of MASs with external disturbance by designing high-gain feedback control method.
We consider the following two high gain quantized consensus protocol to deal with the external disturbances.
Controller 1:
Controller 2:

where β i > 0 is the gain of the controller, φ i (t) = j ∈N i a i j (x i (t)x j (t)) and ξ i (t) = j ∈N i a i j q u2 (x i (t)x j (t)). K is the gain matrix of the controller, q u1 (•), q u2 (•) are uniform quantizers.

Remark 1: Note that [17], [25] considered the consensus problem with the quantized consensus protocol u i (t) = q( j ∈N i a i j (x i (t)x j (t)). The consensus control law with the form u i (t) = j ∈N i a i j q u (x i (t)x j (t)) are investigated in [20]- [22], [24], and [25]. However, the dynamic of every agent in [17] and [20]- [22] is single integrator without taking into account external disturbances. In this paper, we design two controllers to investigate the consensus of MASs with general linear dynamics and external disturbances, which is one of our contributions.

Remark 2: Note that in [23] and [26], the controllers were designed on the basis of the quantized every state. However, we consider the quantized relative state measurements. The reason is that the relative state measurement between neighboring agents is obtained from a practical point of view, such as the formation control of agents. If every agents state is quantized, it increases the quantized error. Thus, the proposed consensus protocol is reasonable.

div.p: Remark 3: It is worth noting that for R 1 and R 2 , by enlarging parameter β β β at the cost of increasing the control energy, the effect of the disturbances can be decreased. Besides, the relative state vector η η η(t) is also affected by the gain θ of the uniform quantizer, P, ς and L. Moreover, η η η(t) depends on the number of agents in the communication graph.

div.head: IV. EVENT-TRIGGERED QUANTIZED CONSENSUS PROTOCOL
div.p: The limited network resources is also a crucial factor for communication of agents. In order to exclude the unnecessary continuous interaction while saving limited network resources in MAS networks, which leads to the event-triggered strategies being taken into account on the basis of the quantized control (7) and (8). Thus, it can greatly decrease the communication load of the multi-agent networks.

Assume that t i k is the event-triggering time sequence of the i th agent denoting t i 0 , t i 1 , . . . , t i ∞ . The two types of the eventtriggered quantized control protocols based on ( 7) and ( 8) are developed as follows.
div.formula: u i (t) = β i K q u1 (φ i (t i k )), i = 1, 2 . . . , N, (23
u i (t) = β i K ξ i (t i k ), i = 1, 2 . . . , N,(24)
div.p: where β i > 0 is the gain of the controller. Remark 4: In the control protocols ( 23) and ( 24), we prefer to choose x j (t i k ) rather than x j (t
div.formula: j k ), k (t) m∈Z + :t >t j m = argmin(t-t j m
div.p: ), as in [30]. The reason is that the controller u i (t) is updated immediately once agent i samples its quantized state value in triggering time instants or receives the sample quantized state value from one of its neighbours. However, the controller does not need updating even though one of its neighbours completes sampling in (23) and (24).

Remark 5: In this paper, the two event-triggered controllers, namely, quantized sum of relative states and sum of quantized relative states, are proposed based on references [20]- [22] that did not consider the limited network resources. However, the event-triggered control approach can effectively reduce the communication load of inter-agent. For sum of quantized relative state in ( 8) and ( 24), the incidence matrix is introduced and for quantized sum of relative state in ( 7) and ( 23) that do not consider the incidence matrix. Besides, for quantized sum of relative states case, the undirected graph can be extended to the directed graph, and for quantized sum of relative states case, it is a question of whether to extend to a directed graph since the incidence matrix does not satisfy L = M T M.
Define the state measurement error corresponding to controller ( 23) and ( 24) as
div.formula: e q u1 i (t) = q u1 (φ i (t i k )) -q u1 (φ i (t)), t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ), (25
div.p: and
div.formula: e q u2 i (t) = ξ i (t i k ) -ξ i (t), t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ). (26
div.p: The trigger functions corresponding to controller ( 23) and ( 24) are designed as
div.formula: t i k+1 = in f {t > t i k | f = e q u1 i (t) 2 -γ 2 e -2ρt > 0, (27
div.p: and
div.formula: t i k+1 = in f {t > t i k | f = e q u2 i (t) 2 -γ 2 e -2ρt > 0,(28)
div.p: where γ > 0, ρ > 0. For t ∈ [t i k , t i k+1 ), the event is triggered if the established error outnumbers the threshold and e q u1 i (t) = e q u2 i (t) = 0.

Remark 6: Note that [24] investigated the consensus problem with the sum of quantized relative state measurements. However, the event-triggered function is designed on the basis of the relative state information and the constant offsets ( [25]), which makes the triggering condition complicated; besides, there is a balance between the frequency of triggering time and the convergence speed. In this paper, the triggering condition does not have the tradeoff, and the design method is more straightforward than that of [24] and [25].

Remark 7: Note that the analysis of the lower bound on the inter-event time intervals of agent is based on continuous time state measurement error e i (t) . However, e i (t) does not work in triggering function (27), since e q u1 (t) is a discontinuous after the quantization of function. Thus, we need to convert the lower bound of inter-event time for e q u1 i (t) to the lower bound of inter-event time e i (t) , and the lower bound of inter-event time for e i (t) is also suitable for e q u1 (t) .

div.p: Remark 9: Note that we mainly study quantized input based on the relative state measurements to discuss the consensus problem with an undirected communication topology in this paper. The reason for investigating the undirected graph is that relative state measurements associates with the incidence matrix, which is different from the conventional Laplacian matrix. However, whether it is possible to extend the undirected graph to a directed graph is an interesting question, and our future work.

div.head: V. SIMULATION EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we offer two simulation examples to verify the theory for the two types of controllers, respectively.

Example 1 [Two Types of Controllers in (7) and (23)]: The example is provided to verify the effectiveness of our proposed controllers in (7) and (23), where the ETC strategy is introduced in (23) on the basis of the controller (7).
Consider the multi-agent systems with the following parameters
and the communication topology of 4 agents is shown in Fig. 1.
According to the matrices A and B, Assumption 1 holds. Then, the Laplacian matrix L can be computed

It is easy to calculate that the eigenvalues of Laplacian matrix L are 0, 1, 1, 4, respectively. Meanwhile, Assumption 1 holds. According to Lemma 3, we can compute r = (0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5) T and the smallest nonzero eigenvalue of matrix L = RL + L T R is 1.

The initial states are x 1,0 = (-3, -2) T , x 2,0 = (8, -6) T , x 3,0 = (10, -9) T , x 4,0 = (-4, 5) T . We also assume that the external disturbances are w 1 = 0.3 cos(0.2t), w 2 = 0.5 si n(t), w 3 = 0.7 cos(t), w 4 = 0.8si n(t). For the consensus protocol (7), β 1 = 0.6, β 2 = 0.6, β 3 = 0.6, β 4 = 0.8. θ = 0.1, γ = 1. We choose the following parameters, (1). δ = 0.1 and ς = 0.2. According to (9), we have P = 3.4720 0.0499 0.0499 1.7317 , K = -0.0499 -1.7317 .

Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 demonstrate the trajectories of the relative state vector η i , i = 1, 2 for the agent 1 with the consensus protocol (23) due to there is no leader in MASs. Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 show the trajectories of the relative state vector η i , i = 1, 2 with the second set of parameters. Remark 10: Considering the parameter ς has an effect on the convergence rate, it is clearly seen from Figs. 23and Figs.4-5 that η i , i = 1, 2 can be reduced by increasing the parameter ς . Note that the simulation results of ( 23) is based on the (7). Thus, we do not present the simulation results of (7).
Example 2 [Two Types of Controllers in ( 8) and ( 24)]: In this example, we consider the 8 agents in communication topology to verify the effectiveness of our theory for the controllers (24).
Consider the multi-agent systems with the following parameters
According to the matrices A and B, Assumption 1 holds. Then, the Laplacian matrix L can be computed

. Let the four agents' initial states as x 1,0 = (-3, -4) T , x 2,0 = (-7, -2) T , x 3,0 = (2, 1) T , x 4,0 = (10, -3) T , x 5,0 = (-10, -2) T , x 6,0 = (1, -10) T , x 7,0 = (1, -2) T , x 8,0 = (5, -6) T . We also assume that the external disturbances are w 1 = 0.4 cos(0.2t), w 2 = 0.5 si n(t), w 3 = 0.6 si n(t), w 4 = 0.6 cos(t), w 5 = 0.4 cos(0.2t), w 6 = w 7 = 0.6 si n(t), w 8 = 0.6 cos(t) respectively. For the consensus protocol (8), we assume β 1 = β 2 = β 3 = β 4 = β 5 = β 6 = β 7 = β 8 = 1. Parameters θ = 0.2, γ = 1.5. We choose the following two set parameters to compare with the resulting being taken into different parameters.
div.formula: According
div.p: (1). δ = 0.06 and ς = 0.1 are considered. Then, according to (9), we have P = 0.9808 0.1238 0.1238 2.4073 , K = -0.1238 -2.4073
(2). δ = 0.06 and ς = 0.8 are considered. Then, according to (9), we have P = 3.0418 0.9345 0.9345 6.6696 , K = -0.9345 -6.6696

Fig. 6 and Fig. 7 demonstrate the scope of the relative state vector η i , where i = 1, 2, for the agent 1 with the eventtriggered quantized consensus protocol (24) and the first set of parameters, while the results of the agents 2-8 are omitted mainly due to the agents 2-8 and the agent 1 have the similar results. Similarly, η i , where i = 1, 2, for the agent 1 with the second set of parameters is shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9. Compared with Fig. 6 and Fig. 8, Fig. 7 and Fig. 9, by increasing the parameter ς , the scope of the relative state vector η i , where i = 1, 2, can be reduced. Considering the simulation method of the quantized consensus protocol ( 8) is similar to that of the event-triggered quantized consensus protocol (24), then, we omit this part.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we discuss four types of the consensus problem for general linear multi-agent systems with two kinds of controllers by combining the quantized control and the event-triggered control mechanism, where the non-bounded disturbance is considered. Inputs based on quantized the sum of relative states and the sum of quantized relative states are firstly designed to solve the consensus problems, respectively. The high gain feedback control method is proposed to reduce the effect of the external disturbance. Besides, in order to save the limited networked resources, the two types of the eventbased communication protocol are designed based on the first case to investigate the consensus problem. Two examples are presented to verify our proposed algorithm for the two types of controllers, respectively. In the future work, we try to consider more complicated situations, such as switching communication topology, time delay and packet loss in the communication network and state-dependent threshold.
